awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Do Ocean Wave Impacts Pose a Hazard to the Stability of West Antarctic Ice Shelves?
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding and being able to more reliably forecast ice mass loss from Antarctica is a critical research priority for Antarctic Science. Massive ice shelves buttress marine terminating glaciers, slowing the rate that land ice reaches the sea and, in turn, restraining the rate of sea level rise. To date, most work has focused on the destabilizing impacts of warmer air and water temperatures, resulting in melting that thins and weakens ice shelves. However, recent findings indicate that sea ice does not protect ice shelves from wave impacts as much as previously thought, which has raised the possibility that tsunamis and other ocean waves could affect shelf stability. This project will assess the potential for increased shelf fracturing from the impact of tsunamis and from heightened wave activity due to climate-driven changes in storm patterns and reduced sea-ice extent by developing models to investigate how wave impacts damage ice shelves. The modeling effort will allow for regional comparisons between large and small ice shelves, and provide an evaluation of the impacts of changing climate and storm patterns on ice shelves, ice sheets, glaciers, and, ultimately, sea level rise. This project will train graduate students in mathematical modeling and interdisciplinary approaches to Earth and ocean sciences.

This project takes a four-pronged approach to estimating the impact of vibrations on ice shelves at the grounding zone due to tsunamis, very long period, infragravity, and storm-driven waves. First, the team will use high-resolution tsunami modeling to investigate the response of ice shelves along the West Antarctic coast to waves originating in different regions of the Pacific Ocean. Second, it will compare the response to wave impacts on grounding zones of narrow and wide ice shelves. Third, it will assess the exposure risk due to storm forcing through a reanalysis of weather and wave model data; and, finally, the team will model the propagation of ocean-wave-induced vibrations in the ice from the shelf front to and across the grounding zone. In combination, this project aims to identify locations along the Antarctic coast that are subject to enhanced, bathymetrically-focused, long-period ocean-wave impacts. Linkages between wave impacts and climate arise from potential changes in sea-ice extent in front of shelves, and changes in the magnitude, frequency, and tracks of storms. Understanding the effects of ocean waves and climate on ice-shelf integrity is critical to anticipate their contribution to the amplitude and timing of sea-level rise. Wave-driven reductions in ice-shelf stability may enhance shelf fragmentation and iceberg calving, reducing ice shelf buttressing and eventually accelerating sea-level rise.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Potential Source Regions for Tsunami Impacting West Antarctic Ice Shelves

Principal Investigators: Peter D. Bromirski, Scripps Institution of Oceanography; Yong Wei, U. of Washington/CICOES, and NOAA/Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory

The continuous advance of the grounded ice sheets to the sea via ice streams results in the formation of floating ice shelves and ice tongues. These massive shelves buttress marine terminating glaciers, slowing the flow rate of land ice across grounding zones (GZ) and reaching the sea, thus restraining the rate of sea level rise. The GZ is the narrow transition region between floating ice and grounded ice streams where the balance of forces controlling ice flow changes rapidly. Near-GZ ice dynamics are affected by GZ geometry, including bedrock slope and slipperiness, and ice and water column thickness. The intrusion of warmer, saltier Circumpolar Deep Water (CDW) into the sub-shelf cavity causes basal melt at the GZ, as well as ice shelf thinning, which reduces restraining land ice buttressing. Importantly, these factors affect GZ dynamics, with potential GZ destabilization by ocean wave impacts resulting in increased flow of grounded ice to the sea.

Understanding and being able to more reliably forecast ice mass loss from Antarctica is a critical research priority for Antarctic Science. Recent findings indicate that sea ice does not protect ice shelves from wave impacts as much as previously thought, which has raised the possibility that tsunamis and other ocean waves could affect shelf stability.

The integrity and evolution of buttressing Antarctic ice shelves are key factors that contribute to the uncertainty in predicting the rate of sea level rise over the coming decades. The acceleration of outlet glaciers after the breakup of the Antarctic Peninsula’s Larsen B Ice Shelf in 2002  underscores the importance of ice shelves to restrain grounded ice from reaching the ocean and raising sea level.

In addition to tides, tsunami and other very long period ocean waves also flex ice shelves, and are minimally affected by the ice shelf surface layer while propagating to grounding zones. Tsunamis produce horizontal displacements in ice shelves associated with dynamical extensional motions that facilitate expansion of existing fractures and crevasses. Importantly, tsunamis have been shown to trigger tabular iceberg calving, such as at the Sulzberger Ice Shelf front (SIS; 76.53oS, 150.16oW) that resulted from 2011 Tōhoku Japan tsunami impacts.

To investigate potential tsunami impacts, this project modeled tsunami propagating from their circum-Pacific source locations to the distant shores of the West Antarctic coast (WAC), where they impact WAC ice shelves and grounding zones. These analyses, based on both observational and numerical data, provide insight on the transformation of tsunami under propagation across the oceans. The models also provide a broader knowledge of the impact of seafloor topography on focusing of tsunami-induced waves and higher-amplitude longer-period tsunami components as they cross the Antarctic continental slope and shelf. The simulations identify West Antarctic Ice Shelf (WAIS) grounding zone locations that are potentially vulnerable to extreme tsunami impacts from particular circum-Pacific source regions.

The effects of tsunami source directionality and amplitudes, and continental slope and sub-shelf bathymetry that focus tsunami amplitudes, were investigated with modeled tsunami. The tsunami model was validated against (1) hydrophone observations of the 2015 Illapel, Chili tsunami arrivals on the seafloor near the front of the Ross Ice Shelf and (2) tide gauge observations of the 2011 Tōhoku, Honshu, Japan tsunami at Cape Roberts, Antarctica (ROBT: 77.03333oS, 163.18333oE). The modeled tsunami amplitudes were comparable to the observations for both events, implying that the modeled amplitudes along the WAC would allow identification of critical tsunamigenic earthquake source locations at circum-Pacific subduction zones that could produce tsunamis that potentially could destabilize ice shelves. The simulations also allow investigation of tsunami amplitude transition across the continental slope (shoaling) and bathymetric-induced changes during propagation across the Antarctic continental shelf.

The potential maximum tsunami amplitude at WAC ice shelves for circum-Pacific tsunami mega-thrust earthquake sources is summarized in Figure 1. In the figure below, the color indicates the average tsunami amplitude (normalized to the maximum of all average amplitudes) along the WAIS region (shaded gray box) for extreme M8.6 earthquake events around the Pacific rim.

More severe tsunami source regions for WAIS impacts are indicated in red. Modeled tsunamis that yield high amplitude waves at West Antarctic Ice Shelves (WAIS) were generated for mega-earthquakes at tsunamigenic thrust fault regions near the Pacific coasts of southwest Mexico, South America, and eastern New Zealand. Tsunami amplitudes from earthquakes in these regions depend on the thrust fault mechanics as well as the associated vertical seafloor displacement. Proximity of the tsunami source to WAIS is also an important factor. The modeling results indicate that tsunami generated along the Pacific coasts of Japan, Alaska, and the U.S. Cascadia subduction zones will not greatly impact vulnerable WAIS regions such as the Thwaites Ice Shelf.
